NARRATORS (OFF SCREEN) Already we've
borrowed two kinds of activities from the other
lessonso Shall we borrow more":
For instance..owould newspaper files throw
any light on Bill Archer's dilemma? Would
books? Magazine articles? Films?
Another loan from list number two. What
are Bill Archer's feelings about all this?
Some students might write a "stream-of-
consciousness" reflection of his thoughts.
Or his wife's thoughts. Or the thoughts of
the men who gave the money.
One teacher used this lesson as a spring¬
board to the study of the mass media and
their influence in public affairs.
BEFORE the lesson her students found out
all they could about the impact of radio,
television, newspapers and magazines in a
political campaign. After the lesson,
they concerned themselves with deciding
whether the television spots were effective
enough to justify the expense and the prob¬
lems it raised.
